newsitem.title: MEXICO: Troubles of Mexican airline Taesa mount -- paper.
newsitem.headline: Troubles of Mexican airline Taesa mount -- paper.

text.p: Mexico's third largest airline Taesa owes money not only to creditor banks but also to the government in taxes and social security payments, the daily El Economista said Tuesday.

Citing unnamed sources, the daily said the debts of the airline amount to $400 million to seven creditor banks, while government debts total 100 million pesos to the Finance Ministry and the Mexican Social Security Institute.
El Economista reported last week that two Mexican banks are seeking the liquidation of Taesa because the airline has lost two-thirds of its share capital and is unable to pay debts.
El Economista has said that Bancomer, Mexico's second largest bank, recently filed a petition in a Mexico City court for Taesa to be declared bankrupt.
A Bancomer spokesman at that time was not able to confirm the suit against Taesa. Neither Taesa nor Bancomer spokesmen could be reached for comment this morning.

Taesa, an airline that grew rapidly during the administration of former president Carlos Salinas (1988-1994), had a 30 percent market share in that period but then suffered, as all Mexican airlines did, in the December 1994 devaluation.
